The extent to which Silicon Valley forsakes and ignores Oakland is reprehensible. Irresponsible to reap billions and ignore your area.
As the city pays consultants thousands and millions to give them advice on how to help, we should be crowdsourcing solutions for free too.
I think there's a lot of room to help Oakland through projects like @Shine_in_Peace and @OpenOakland and you don't need to be local to help.
But it's hard for me as someone living across the country to do things to "help". Should I even be? Why? Oakland's got my heart.
Occupy Oakland made me really invested in the place, the local government, the people in a way I've not experienced before. My takeaway.
I left Oakland over a year ago, and to this day I think about it's beauty and it's problems nearly every day. I've never had a place do that
I have all of these presumptions about Mexico and Mexicans that I KNOW are wrong, but rarely have the chance to question them.
Mexican culture is really interesting and I wish I could see it better without the weight of American anti-Mexican racism in my head.
@lisawilliams Yeah, so sorry I saw your other tweet but totally blanked on it. Shoot me an email at ejfox@ejfox.com
If I could be part of whatever it is that journalism turns into on the web, that would be really great, thanks.
I don’t think the big news orgs of yore will grow into the same position on the web. There will be a new, native contender to take that spot
I just think its frustrating to put so much energy into making the old things work in a new environment, instead of trying new things.
What an incredible hard and insurmountable-looking problem: to change how news/journalism is approached and delivered. But we’re all trying.
The internet needs its own newsroom. Or at least one that understands it and can treat it with respect.
I imagine the day when people say “Oh man did you see that story on Guantanamo?” the same way they say “Did you see Sharknado?”
The whole idea of journalism has been warped. I want to start over in the modern age. How many non-blog news orgs have started since 95?
Its a cause/effect problem. News orgs goals are to “get the most eyeballs” instead of be the best / most accurate / most informative source
The problem is that journalists, by-and-large, don’t really make content worth paying for. When they do, the case for why isnt made enough.
Making your news org dependent on Ads is a mistake they are still trying to unravel now. People are happy to pay for good content.
This American Life has set a wonderful model: if you do journalism that is really great, and moving, people will pay to help you do it.
Why is it that no news source really feels “native” to the internet?
I want a 24/hr news site. Not a TV channel. Livestreamers. Tweeters. Longreads. Dataviz. Interviews. Analysis.  No shitty ads. No gimmicks.
I’m kind of sick of seeing smart journos going to old orgs to help them “update” coverage for new era. Stop upgrading dinosaurs. Move on.
Doing the news for the sake of the greater good is important, but no longer the only requirement. Content has to be quality. Delivered well.
No wonder my generation doesn’t give a shit about the news: look at its quality compared to everything else? News needs to be competitive
There is no news source for my generation. Except, kind of, VICE. No one else consistently covers issues I care about, or covers them well.
I just cant help but think that starting fresh would help out a lot. Try new approaches, mediums, without tacking them on to old relics.
From what I can tell the modern way to change the way the news is delivered is to become a billionaire and buy a newsroom, but, y’know…
Want to start my own news organization for the modern era but have no idea where to start

Got some hardcore creative urges, but sleep moreso. Time to pass out, methinks. Tomorrow I need to clean so people can chill.
